Key Laboratory for Advanced Materials, Research Institute of Industrial Catalysis, School of Chemistry and Molecular Engineering, East China University of Science and Technology Shanghai 200237 China This work demonstrated a facile methodology to construct single Nb site catalysts with merely 0.63 wt% Nb by employing α-hydroxy carboxylic acid-functionalized cotton fiber as green and sustainable supporting material. The as-synthesized catalysts have been characterized thoroughly and exhibited a superior catalytic activity for selective oxidation of aniline into azoxybenzene with nearly 100% utilization efficiency of H2O2 under mild and green conditions. Notably, it demonstrated the highest TOF (4806 h−1) among the currently reported heterogeneous catalysts. Moreover, the catalyst has steadily been operated under continuous-flow conditions, which afforded significant benefits compared to batch processes as reported in these transformations. The activity test and catalyst characterization indicated that the atomically dispersed Nb-peroxo coordination centers were actually catalytic sites. Especially, the α-hydroxy carboxylic acid groups on cotton fiber played an important role in coordinating/stabilizing single Nb site. Moreover, 1H MAS NMR spectra verified that there exists an acid-base interaction between arylamines and free α-hydroxy carboxylic acid groups covalently grafted on cotton fiber, which was favorable for adsorption and activation of the substrates. Mechanism studies indicated that the azoxy derivatives were produced through condensation step between N-phenylhydroxylamine and nitrosobenzene rather than direct oxidation of azobenzene. The work provides an economical and environmentally friendly approach to construct single–site catalysts for the oxidation catalysis. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Cotton fiber Nb Single-site Arylamine Azoxybenzene Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Oxidation of aniline is one of the most prominent reactions in industrial production of commodity chemicals as well as fine chemicals and pharmaceuticals [1]. The oxidation of aniline can provide a direct access to value-added products containing N-phenylhydroxylamine, nitrosobenzen, nitrobenzene, azobenzene and azoxybenzene [2–4]. Amongst these products, the azoxybenzene has aroused much attention from academia and industry due to its unique properties. Azoxybenzenes are high value-added chemicals widely utilized in the industry as reducing agents, drug intermediates, polymerization inhibitors and dyes [5–7]. In addition, some derivatives of azoxybenzenes can be employed as liquid crystals in electronic displays [8]. Meanwhile, azoxybenzene can be straightforwardly transformed into hydroxyazobenzene with the aid of acid under the course of Wallach rearrangement, thus providing facile methodology to obtain hydroxyazobenzene in organic synthesis [9]. Generally, azoxybenzene can be produced by reductive and oxidative routes [10,11]. Much efforts have been devoted to the reductive pathway, in which noble-metal catalysts including CeO2-encapsulated Au nanostructures and Ru single atom catalysts were employed [12,13]. Moreover, expensive reducing agents (NaBH4, N2H4, etc.) and deleterious additives (KOH, n-butylamine and so on) were always involved [14–17], which increased the cost of operation and caused environmental problems. On the other hand, the oxidative route provided an alternative pathway for the synthesis of azoxybenzenes. It has been reported that peracetic acid, BaMnO4, tert-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP), Hg(OAc)2 and Pb(OAc)4 could be utilized as stoichiometric oxidants for oxidation of arylamines [18,19]. However, these oxidants were less environmentally friendly than hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) and oxygen (O2). As a benign oxidant, H2O2 could be activated at lower temperature compared with O2 and H2O is produced as a sole by-product. Hitherto, many heterogeneous catalysts have been studied for the oxidation of aniline with H2O2 as green oxidant. Ti-based materials [20,21], Zr(OH)4 [22], spinel CuCr2O4 [23], Ag-Fe2O3 [24], Ag-WO3 and δ-FeOOH supported-amorphous niobium oxyhydroxide were utilized for the selective oxidation of arylamines with TOF varying from 0.2 to 95 h−1 [25,26]. Particularly, Nb2O5-scCO2 possessing high-surface area prepared with a supercritical-CO2-assisted technique showed excellent performance for oxidative coupling of aniline with the TOF of 305 h−1 [27]. Although great progress has been achieved in the heterogeneous oxidation of arylamines, these transformations are normally carried out under batchwise conditions and the catalytic efficiency needs further to be enhanced. Notably, continuous-flow processes as alternative technology offers significant processing advantages including improvement in efficiency, product quality, scalability and safety by use of heterogeneous catalysis [28]. Consequently, the design of a green, robust and efficient catalytic system enabling continuous-flow oxidation of aniline to azoxybenzene is highly promising. Single-atom catalyst (SAC) has been a hot topic in catalysis field because of its unique properties that catalytic performance can be tuned by the size and chemical environment of the active sites [29]. SACs own giant advantage in terms of 100% atom-utilization efficiency compared with corresponding clusters and nanoparticles, and thus reducing the cost of catalyst. Owing to the unique structure and electronic properties, SACs exhibited better catalytic activity and selectivity in comparison with nanoparticle catalysts in a variety of heterogenous catalysis containing electrocatalysis, water-gas shift [30], selective hydrogenation [31], CO oxidation [32], and so on. SACs can be regarded as a bridge between heterogeneous and homogeneous catalysts because of atomically dispersed active sites and local coordination environment functioning as rigid ligands toward metal atoms. However, the surface energy of metal atoms increased with the decrease of size and single atoms tended to migration and aggregated to nanoparticles during the course of pre-activation and catalytic reaction. Therefore, the interactions between metal atoms and support play a vital role in anchoring single atoms on support, enhancing the stability of SACs. As a result, the surface of the supports tethering specific functional groups including hydroxyl, carboxyl, amino groups, etc. might provide effective anchor sites for single metal atoms [33]. Cotton fiber is a green and sustainable bio-based material, of which the surface possesses plentiful hydroxyl groups [34]. There are many merits for cotton fiber such as abundance, breathability, low cost, nontoxicity, excellent biodegradability, elasticity and easy handling. Consequently, it is a class of material extensively utilized in the textile industry [35]. Meanwhile, continuous efforts have been dedicated to the surface modification of cotton fiber to confer it special properties including water repellence [36], antimicrobial effect [37], fire resistance [38], UV protection and self-cleaning ability [39,40]. Additionally, the carbonization of cotton fiber can afford various valuable carbonaceous materials with specific structure utilized for electrochemistry and chemical adsorption [41,42]. Moreover, thanks to the high specific surface area and hygroscopic property beneficial for mass transfer during catalytic reaction, the modified cotton fiber can be used as supporting material for immobilization of photocatalyst and metal nanoparticles in catalysis [43]. As a result, cotton fiber as a material immobilizing metal species is highly attractive for catalytic application. According to our previous work, it was found that Nb-based salts displayed high catalytic performance for the catalytic oxidative coupling of arylamines with H2O2 as benign oxidant under mild conditions [44]. However, the homogeneous Nb-based salts failed to be applied to continuous-flow process. Considering that α-hydroxy carboxylic acid group can form stable coordination with Nb sites [45], we envisaged that α-hydroxy carboxylic acid can react with surface hydroxyl groups of cotton fiber to form a single ester linkage via esterification, which could provide plenty of anchors to attach Nb sites through coordination interaction, thus gaining single Nb site catalyst. On the basis of the above conception, a cotton fiber-supported atomically dispersed Nb-based catalyst was fabricated and exhibited outstanding catalytic performance for the oxidative coupling of arylamines utilizing H2O2 under very mild conditions. Meanwhile, due to superior shape adaptive, the cotton fiber-anchored single Nb site catalyst can be employed for the oxidative coupling of aniline in homemade continuous-flow reactor, which has the potential for further industrial application. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first work that aniline was converted into azoxybenzene almost quantitatively under continuous-flow conditions. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Niobium pentoxide (Nb2O5), acetic acid (HOAc) and potassium hydroxide (KOH) were obtained from Bide Pharmatech Ltd. Malic acid (MA), citric acid (CA), tartaric acid (H4tart), succinic acid (SA), ammonium hydroxide (NH3·H2O) and hydrogen peroxide (30 wt%, H2O2) were provided by Aladdin. Degreasing cotton was provided by Bide Pharmatech Ltd to be utilized as supporting material. Aniline and other aromatic amines were purchased from Shanghai Titan Scientific Co., Ltd. Nitrosobenzene, nitrobenzene, zinc powder and ammonium chloride were obtained from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd. Ethanol, n-hexane, ethyl acetate, acetonitrile and methanol were supplied by Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, People’s Republic of China) as reaction solvents. Toluene was supplied by Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd utilized as internal standard in gas chromatography (GC) analysis. Sodium hydroxide (NaOH) and hydrochloric acid (37%, HCl) were purchased from Aladdin. Acetonitrile (HPLC) was provided by Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd as mobile phase. 2.2 Catalyst preparation 2.2.1 Synthesis of niobic acid (Nb2O5·nH2O) The Nb2O5·nH2O was prepared according to previously reported literature [46]. Firstly, KOH and Nb2O5 were sintered at 550 °C for 6 h with a certain molar ratio (nKOH/Nb2O5 =10). Then, the mixture was dissolved in water and the insoluble content was removed by filtration. The HOAc was added to the filtrate to adjust the pH around 3 and amounts of white precipitate formed immediately. Subsequently, the precipitate was washed fully with a great deal of water to ensure that HOAc was removed, which was then dried at 50 °C for 2 h. The water content was measured and found to be about 75% in niobic acid. 2.2.2 Surface modification of the cotton fiber via esterification The cotton fiber was modified through esterification according to previous literature [47]. As a typical example, 0.5 g of MA was dissolved in 50 mL of H2O and 0.5 g of degreasing cotton was soaked in it. Then the mixture was ultrasound for 15 min to ensure the uniform dispersion of MA on the surface of cotton fiber. Subsequently, H2O was evaporated at 80 °C and esterification was conducted at 120 °C with different time (0.5 h, 1 h, 3 h, 6 h, 9 h, 12 h, etc.). After esterification, the cotton fiber was washed with large amounts of H2O to remove free MA until the pH of the solution reached 7. Finally, the cotton fiber was dried and the resulting material was denoted as Cot-MA-t (t represented time of esterification). Similarly, the cotton fiber modified with CA or H4tart was designated as Cot-CA-t or Cot-Tart-t respectively, (where t represented time of esterification). 2.2.3 Preparation of cotton fiber-anchored single Nb site catalyst As a typical example, the single Nb site catalyst was prepared by taking Cot-MA-t as a support. At first, the Cot-MA-t was treated with NH3·H2O in order to deprotonation of MA on the surface of the modified cotton fiber, which enabled Nb sites to coordinate with α-hydroxyl carboxylic acid groups on the surface of cotton fiber. Subsequently, 1.2 g of Nb2O5·nH2O was dispersed in 1 mL H2O and 3 mL H2O2 was added. The mixture was stirred at 0 °C until the solution became clear. Next, the solution was diluted to 50 mL with H2O and 0.3 g of pre-treated modified cotton fiber was soaked. The mixture was stirred for 0.5 h at 0 °C to ensure sufficient coordination between Nb sites and α-hydroxyl carboxylic acid group on the modified cotton fiber. Then the cotton fiber was rinsed with plenty of H2O and H2O2 to remove free Nb species. Finally, the cotton fiber-derived catalyst was dried at 60 °C and denoted as Cot-MA-t-Nb. Likewise, the catalysts-derived from Cot-CA-t and Cot-Tart-t were denoted as Cot-CA-t-Nb and Cot-Tart-t-Nb respectively. Additionally, Cot-SA-12-Nb was prepared in a similar procedure with that of Cot-MA-12-Nb except that SA was used rather than MA. For the sake of comparison, Cot-Nb catalyst was prepared in a similar procedure with Cot-MA-t-Nb except that the raw cotton was directly used without esterification procedure. Generally, 1.2 g Nb2O5·nH2O was dispersed in 1 mL H2O and 3 mL H2O2 was added. The mixture was stirred at 0 °C until the solution became clear. Next, the solution was diluted to 50 mL with H2O and 0.3 g original degreasing cotton was soaked. The mixture was stirred for 0.5 h at 0 °C. Then the cotton fiber was rinsed with plenty of H2O and H2O2 to remove free Nb species. Finally, the cotton fiber was dried at 60 °C and the resulting catalyst was denoted as Cot-Nb. Furthermore, Cot-Nb-IM catalyst was also prepared via an impregnation method. Briefly, a certain amount of Nb2O5·nH2O was reacted with H2O2 to obtain clear solution. Then, the solution was evenly adsorbed on the raw cotton without washing procedure, which was then dried at 60 °C to get Cot-Nb-IM catalyst, where the loading of Nb species was the same as that of Cot-MA-12-Nb. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The catalyst characterization can be found in supporting information. 2.4 Catalytic oxidation test For batch reaction, the selective oxidation of arylamines was performed in liquid phase with a 25 mL Schlenk flask equipped with a magnetic stirrer. In a typical procedure, 2 mmol arylamines, 3 mmol H2O2 and toluene (an internal standard) were dissolved in 2 mL ethanol and charged into a 25 mL Schlenk flask. Then 25 mg of the catalyst was added and mixture was stirred at 60 °C. The reaction solution was withdrawn periodically for analysis using gas chromatography (GC). The N-phenylhydroxylamine was detected via high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC). In catalyst recycling, the catalyst was simply separated from the reaction solution by grabbing out with tweezers, squeezing and washed with ethanol several times. The rinsed catalyst was then dried at 60 °C and reused for next run. For continuous-flow process, 0.5 g of catalyst was sandwiched in the isothermal section of the glass reaction tube with glass ball to support the catalyst, and the rest of the tube was filled with glass ball. The diameter of the glass ball was 3–4 mm. The inner diameter of reactor tube was 25 mm. The external diameter of reactor tube was around 38 mm. In addition, the length of reactor tube was about 200 mm. The aniline and H2O2 were dissolved in ethanol and the concentration of each was 1.61 M and 2.40 M respectively. The ethanol solution of aniline and H2O2 were pumped into glass reaction tube, respectively with flow rate of 0.08 mL/min. Then the solution flowed through the glass ball and was thoroughly mixed. The oxidation of aniline took place with the mixed solution flowing through the catalyst. Meanwhile, the reaction temperature was controlled at 60 °C by hot water circulator in a sandwich glass. The effluent solution was quantitatively analyzed by gas chromatography (GC). For mechanism studies, N-phenylhydroxylamine was synthesized by previously reported procedure [48] and used as a substrate under the oxidation conditions. Briefly, nitrobenzene (12.3 g, 100 mmol) and ammonium chloride (6.4 g, 120 mmol) were mixed in H2O (60 mL). Then, zinc powder (14.4 g, 220 mmol) was added slowly in portions under vigorous stirring to the mixed solution, keeping the temperature below 65 °C. The reaction solution was filtered after 4 h maintaining hot, saturated with NaCl, extracted with CH2Cl2 and concentrated to approximately 30 mL. Subsequently, petroleum ether was added to CH2Cl2 and N-phenylhydroxylamine was recrystallized from the mixed solution as white solid (wool-like). 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 8.30 (d, 1 H), 8,23 (s, 1 H), 7.17 (dd, 2 H), 6.87 (d, 2 H), 6.75 (t, 1 H); 13C NMR (100 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 152.53, 128.87, 119.71, 113.44 (Fig. S1). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization The preparation procedure of cotton fiber-anchored single Nb site catalysts included the esterification of cotton fiber by α-hydroxyl carboxylic acid and subsequent coordination with Nb-peroxo species. As a typical example, it was seen from Scheme 1 that α-hydroxy carboxylic acids (MA) were firstly covalently conjugated to the surface of cotton fiber via esterification reaction, which can provide a plenty of anchors for Nb sites. Then, niobic acid was stirred with H2O2 at 0 °C and transformed into peroxoniobate species. Once the solution became clear, the functionalized cotton fiber was soaked in it for enough time. After the Nb species was anchored on cotton fiber by coordination, the cotton fiber was rinsed and washed fully with H2O and H2O2 to remove free Nb species. Finally, the resulting catalysts were dried at 60 °C and denoted as cotton fiber-anchored single Nb site catalyst. For comparison, Nb-based catalysts derived from impregnation have also been prepared. The Nb contents of all the catalysts were determined by ICP-AES and given in Table S1. It should be noted that surface esterification is very crucial for the immobilization of Nb species (Table S1, entries 1–6), and otherwise almost all the Nb species were rinsed out by water or H2O2 treatment (Table S1, entry 7) on the raw cotton fiber, confirming that α-hydroxy carboxylic acids also played an indispensable role in coordinating/immobilizing Nb species [49]. Conversely, linear carboxylic acid like SA cannot anchor Nb species effectively due to weak coordination interaction of carboxylic group with Nb species (Table S1, entry 8). Additionally, the surface areas of the catalysts were determined and listed in Table S2, indicating that the cotton fiber-anchored Nb catalysts showed a poor porosity. Firstly, the surface acid density of the functionalized cotton fiber was determined by titration considering that α-hydroxy carboxylic acid groups grafted on cotton fiber acted as anchors for Nb sites. As shown in Fig. S2, the acid density on the modified cotton fiber increased with esterification time no matter for CA, MA and H4tart. Eventually, the acid density no longer increased after 12 h, which may be ascribed to reaction equilibrium of esterification of the carboxylic acid groups and the hydroxy groups in the cellulose fiber. Especially, the α-hydroxy carboxylic acids offered different esterification efficiency even under the same reaction time. It can be seen that MA and CA gave the similar esterification efficiency. However, H4tart afforded poor reactivity even after 12 h. This may be related to the structure of carboxylic groups of H4tart, in which the vicinal hydroxyl groups might hamper the esterification reaction due to steric factor [50]. Comparatively, for MA and CA, the carboxylic group without ortho-hydroxyl substituent was more favorable for the esterification of the hydroxy groups in the cellulose fiber. As shown in Table S1, high acid density was favorable for immobilizing Nb species. Based on results above, MA was chosen to modify the surface of cotton fiber due to high esterification efficiency and more simple structure. Notably, the esterification reaction actually reached an equilibrium after 12 h and the acid density was obtained as high as 2.8 mmol·g−1 (Fig. S2a and b). Next, the as-synthesized cotton fiber-anchored single Nb site catalysts were characterized via FT-IR spectroscopy. For commercial Nb2O5, the band around 3445 cm−1 was attributed to the OH stretching of Nb-OH ( Fig. 1a, left) [51]. The band at 1630 cm−1 was assigned to the adsorbed water molecules. In addition, the bands near 878 cm−1 and 625 cm−1 were characteristic for the distorted octahedral NbO6 containing NbO bond. On the other hand, the raw cotton displayed a band near 3338 cm−1, which can be ascribed to the vibration of surface hydroxy groups (Fig. 1b, left), and the band around 2895 cm−1 was assigned to the vibration of C-H in the skeleton of cotton fiber [52]. Additionally, the band near 1027 cm−1 was due to the vibration of C-O in the skeleton of cotton fiber [53]. However, after the surface of raw cotton fiber was functionalized with MA, a new band at 1727 cm−1 appeared which was characteristic for the vibration of carboxylic acid [54], demonstrating that MA was covalently conjugated to the surface of raw cotton fiber via esterification (Fig. 1c, left). Meanwhile, the characteristic bands assigning to C-O and C-H vibration remained intact. Notably, after Nb species was coordinated with surface functional groups on the cotton fiber, the resulting cotton fiber-anchored single Nb site catalyst showed the similar vibration bands as that of the modified cotton fiber (Fig. 1c vs 1d, left). No bands corresponding to the Nb species were observed, which was attributed to the ultralow loading (0.63%) and high dispersion of Nb species. Then, the catalysts were investigated by X-ray diffraction (XRD) and displayed in Fig. 1 (right). As shown in Fig. 1a (right), the commercial Nb2O5 exhibited the representative diffraction peaks of orthorhombic phase (JCPDS 30–0873) [55]. The diffraction peaks at 2θ of 22.6, 28.4, 29.0, 36.7, 37.1, 46.2, 51.0 and 55.2° can be ascribed to the planes of (001), (180), (200), (181), (201), (002), (380) and (202), respectively. The raw cotton fiber displayed a very intense peak at 2θ = 22.6°, which was related to the (002) plane in cotton fiber. The two low intensity peaks near 14.7° and 16.7° can be corresponded to the (101) plane in cotton fiber. Additionally, low intensity peak at the 2θ position of 34.4° can be assigned to (040) plane (Fig. 1b, right). The abovementioned peaks were typical of the cellulose-I crystalline form [56]. Notably, the diffraction pattern of the functionalized cotton fiber was highly similar to that of the raw cotton fiber, demonstrating that the covalently grafted MA did not significantly affect the crystal structure of cotton fiber (Fig. 1c vs b, right). After anchoring Nb species, the resulting Nb catalyst showed the characteristic patterns of cotton fibers (Fig. 1d, right). Meanwhile, no peaks belong to the Nb species was observed, which might be on account of the atomically dispersed Nb sites. The typical surface morphology of raw cotton, the functionalized cotton fiber and cotton fiber-anchored single Nb site catalyst were studied by SEM. As shown in Fig. 2a and b, the typical morphology of raw cotton fiber was displayed at different magnifications, exhibiting a typical spiral structure with diameters of 20 µm scale bar. The surface of cotton fabrics was relatively smooth. After the cotton fiber was esterified with MA, the cellulose structure of the functionalized cotton fiber actually reserved in comparison with raw cotton fiber, indicating that esterification did not destroy the fibrous microstructures of raw cotton (Fig. 2c and d) [57]. Notably, after Nb species was immobilized on the modified cotton fiber, the resulting cotton fiber-anchored Nb catalyst exhibited no significant change in the surface morphology (Fig. 2e and f). Moreover, the Nb2O5 particles cannot be seen on the surface of the modified cotton fiber, indicating that the Nb species on cotton fiber were highly dispersed and the size of Nb species was below the detection limit of SEM, which was consistent with the XRD characterization (Fig. 1d, right). Subsequently, the dispersion state of Nb sites on the cotton fiber was investigated by HAADF-STEM. As shown in Fig. 2g, no Nb2O5 nanoparticles were identified in the sample. EDS mapping (Fig. 2h-j) displayed a nearly homogeneous elemental distribution of C, O and Nb. To determine whether the Nb sites in cotton fiber-anchored catalyst are atomically dispersed, atomic-resolution HAADF-STEM imaging was further conducted. The result exhibited that well-defined Nb single sites were formed, distributing uniformly within the functionalized cotton fiber support (red circle in Fig. 2k). The large area of bright spots in the upper right corner was mainly due to the thick cotton fiber layer (Fig. 2k). For comparison, aberration-corrected HAADF-STEM image of Cot-Nb catalyst was also shown in Fig. S3. Energy-dispersive X-ray spectrum failed to detect Nb signal because of its ultralow loading. However, the aggregated Nb species was discernable from HAADF-STEM image on Cot-Nb catalyst even if the loading Nb (0.02%) was very low (Fig. S3b). Similarly, the raw cotton-derived Cot-Nb-IM catalyst even displayed much more serious aggregation even at the same Nb loading as that of Cot-MA-12 (0.63%) (Fig. S3g). Consequently, the surface modification of cotton fiber with the covalently conjugated MA contributed definitely to atomically dispersed Nb sites on Cot-MA-12-Nb catalyst due to the coordination interaction. X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) was conducted to elucidate local atomic environment of Nb sites in cotton fiber-anchored Nb catalyst. Fig. 3a displayed the normalized XANES of the Nb K-edge of Nb foil, Nb2O5, Cot-Nb and Cot-MA-12-Nb. The Nb foil exhibited the lowest edge energy in comparison with other catalysts containing Nb due to the lowest valent state (0) for the Nb foil. This red shift was along with the increase in electron binding energy at higher oxidation states [58]. A weak pre-edge shoulder existed in Nb2O5, which was characteristic for five valent states of Nb and absent for other oxidation states irrespective of geometry [59]. The similar feature was observed for Cot-Nb and Cot-MA-12-Nb catalysts. The observation was ascribed to an electronic transition from the 1 s-orbital to the 4d-orbital manifold. Additionally, there was weak absorption signal from Cot-Nb due to extremely low loading of Nb on cotton fiber, implying that raw cotton failed to anchor Nb sites strongly. Meanwhile, Nb neighbor shells were studied by the k 3-weighted Nb K-edge EXAFS illustrated in Fig. 3b. A bonding peak near 2.5 Å attributed to Nb-Nb bonding was observed for Nb foil. An asymmetrical peak of 3.6 Å corresponded to the shortest Nb-Nb coordination appeared for Nb2O5. In addition, a bonding peak near 1.6 Å was related to first coordination shell of Nb-O in Nb2O5 [60], which can also be seen in Cot-Nb, demonstrating that Nb species on the surface of raw cotton fiber may be Nb2O5 and other aggregated Nb species rather than single Nb sites. Moreover, the peak at 1.5 Å was observed for Cot-MA-12-Nb, which was related to side-on metal-peroxo bonds according to our previously reported work. The peaks around 1.6 Å and 3.6 Å were absent for Cot-MA-12-Nb, indicating that Nb species existed on the surface of functionalized cotton fiber as atomically dispersive single sites. The observation confirmed that MA conjugated covalently to the surface of cotton fiber provided anchors for Nb sites, thus being beneficial to form single Nb sites and corroborated the conclusion from HAADF-STEM. Moreover, the local environment of Nb in cotton fiber-based catalysts was investigated in three dimensions via decomposition of the k-space and R-space signals. The wavelet transform (WT) plots of the catalysts were displayed in Fig. 3 where the color intensity was in relation to WT modulus corresponding to the decomposition of the EXAFS amplitude term. It can be intuitively seen that the highest intensity in k-space was at 8 Å−1 for Nb foil, which was assigned to Nb-Nb bond. Additionally, the highest intensity for Nb-O in k-space for Nb2O5, Cot-Nb and Cot-MA-12-Nb located at 5 Å−1, 3 Å−1 and 5 Å−1 respectively. The wavelet transforms of χ(k) further proved that the aggregated Nb species were absent in Cot-MA-12-Nb catalyst. 3.2 Catalytic performance Since the surface-grafted α-hydroxyl carboxylic acid groups was coordinated with Nb sites, the anchored Nb contents would be highly relevant to acid density as shown in Scheme 1. As depicted in Fig. 4a, the anchored Nb contents increased with the acid density. Theoretically, one molecule of α-hydroxy carboxylic acid can coordinate one Nb atom. However, the actual Nb loading was much lower than the calculated value likely due to the steric hindrance (Fig. 4a). This confirmed that the surface of the modified cotton fiber actually contained a plenty of free carboxylic acid groups without Nb coordination. Notably, the conversion of aniline exhibited a highly linear relationship with the Nb contents (Fig. 4b). The observation further confirmed that catalytic activity was closely relevant to single Nb sites that were uniformly distributed on functionalized cotton fiber surface as revealed from Figs. 2 and 3. Afterward, the oxidative coupling of aniline was performed as a benchmark reaction utilizing H2O2 as an oxidant under batchwise conditions. As exhibited in Table 1, the H2O2 itself could hardly convert aniline to azoxybenzene (Table 1, entry 1). Similarly, the commercial Nb2O5 and raw cotton fiber displayed very poor catalytic performance for the conversion of aniline (Table 1, entry 2 and 3). In addition, Cot-Nb failed to catalyze aniline effectively due to extremely low loading of Nb (0.02%) (Table 1, entry 4), which was attributed to the lack of surface ligand (α-hydroxyl carboxylic acid groups) in raw cotton fiber, leading to Nb removal after washing with H2O and H2O2 in the course of catalyst preparation (Table S1). Moreover, the reaction afforded poor activity with the sole MA as catalyst (Table 1, entry 5). Surprisingly, once the MA-functionalized cotton fiber was employed as support to anchor Nb species, the resulting Cot-MA-12-Nb catalyst can convert all aniline into azoxybenzene almost quantitatively under the same conditions (Table 1, entry 6). The same activity can be observed with Cot-CA-12-Nb catalyst due to similar loading of Nb species (Table 1, entry 7). However, Cot-Tart-12-Nb showed an inferior activity to Cot-MA-12-Nb and Cot-CA-12-Nb catalysts (Table 1, entry 8), resulting from much lower Nb loading on Cot-Tart-12-Nb (Table S1). Besides, if MA was replaced by SA, the obtaining Cot-SA-12-Nb catalyst showed very poor catalytic performance for oxidative coupling of aniline (Table 1, entry 9), which was mainly due to that SA modification on cotton fiber could not provide effective anchors for Nb sites. These results suggested strongly that surface esterification of cotton fiber by α-hydroxy carboxylic acid played an indispensable role in constructing highly active Nb sites for the oxidative coupling of aniline. Especially, Cot-Nb-IM catalyst showed much lower catalytic activity than Cot-MA-12-Nb even at the same Nb loading (Table 1, entry 10), indicating that single Nb sites were actually catalytic sites and the comparatively aggregated Nb species in Cot-Nb-IM catalyst would contribute less to the oxidation activity. Subsequently, the oxidation of aniline was performed under different solvent conditions by use of Cot-MA-12-Nb as a catalyst. As can be seen in Table S3, the reaction afforded good activity but moderate selectivity under solvent-free conditions, which was mainly ascribed to the violent exothermic reaction in the oxidation of aniline, leading to the occurrence of over oxidation (Table S3, entry 1). Meanwhile, although aniline showed a limited solubility in H2O (36 mg mL−1, 20 °C), good catalytic performance was still achieved in aqueous phase. In contrast to our previous work, the reaction can proceed very smoothly even in hydrophobic solvents such as n-hexane and ethyl acetate (Table S3, entry 3 and 4), confirming that the reaction might occur on the surface of the catalysts rather than in liquid phase. Besides, the Cot-MA-12-Nb catalyst also afforded outstanding catalytic performance in polar media like acetonitrile, methanol and ethanol (Table S3, entries 5–7). The atomic dispersion of Nb sites and amphiphilic surface of cotton fiber contributed to easy accessibility of substrate molecules to catalytically active Nb sites in either polar or weak polar media. In the following activity evaluation, ethanol was chosen as a green solvent attributable to nontoxicity and low volatility. Next, the influence of the H2O2 dosage on oxidative coupling of aniline was studied. As illustrated in Fig. S4, the conversion of aniline increased with the increase of the amount of H2O2 until 1.5 equivalents, which was equal to stoichiometric ratio according to the previous work [27]. The results revealed that the utilization efficiency of H2O2 was ca. 100% on the Cot-MA-12-Nb. Moreover, the selectivity for azoxybenzene did not decline and no over-oxidized product was determined albeit excessive H2O2 was added, implying that superior catalytic performance can be attained in a wide series of operation conditions for the current cotton fiber-anchored single Nb site catalyst. Then, the dependence of conversion rate of aniline on temperature was conducted with Cot-MA-12-Nb. As can be seen in Fig. 5a, the reaction rate increased with reaction temperature under 30–60 °C. The TOF for Cot-MA-12-Nb was calculated as 4806 h−1 at 60 °C at low conversions (<20%). Besides, the product distribution/time profiles showed that N-phenylhydroxylamine and nitrosobenzene were produced at the initial stage of reaction. Thereafter, azoxybenzene was formed selectively along with fast consumption of N-phenylhydroxylamine and nitrosobenzene, implying that N-phenylhydroxylamine and nitrosobenzene were the key reaction intermediates for the oxidation of aniline (Fig. 5b, insert). Later, the activity tests were conducted to examine the scope of substrates under batchwise reaction conditions on Cot-MA-12-Nb. As depicted in Table 2, various arylamines bearing electron-deficient substituents or electron-rich groups could be all transformed into corresponding azoxy derivatives nearly quantitatively (Table 2, entries 1–8). However, the arylamine with electron-withdrawing substituent at the ortho position would require more time to give azoxy derivatives on account of steric hindrance and electronic effect (Table 2, entry 3). The arylamines with sensitive functional groups such as hydroxymethyl and vinyl were also examined. It can be seen that 4-amino benzyl alcohol can be oxidized quantitatively into corresponding azoxy products and meantime hydroxymethyl group maintained intact (Table 2, entry 8). Nevertheless, the oxidation of 4-amino styrene afforded only ca. 40% selectivity toward azoxy compound along with the production of insoluble compounds owing to polymerization of unsaturated double bonds (Table 2, entry 9). Especially, 3-amino pyridine can be oxidized into the corresponding azoxy compound quantitatively, and comparatively 2-amino pyridine could hardly be oxidized under the similar conditions, which may be attributable to that 2-amino pyridine as bidentate ligand can “poison” the Nb active sites via strong coordination (Table 2, entry 11). In addition, poor activity was observed for 2-naphthylamine on account of steric and electronic effect (Table 2, entry 12). Overall, Cot-MA-12-Nb showed outstanding catalytic performance for various arylamines with high TOF values which were higher than the currently reported values of heterogeneous catalysts, indicating universal applicability of the cotton fiber-anchored single Nb site catalyst. Meanwhile, the as-obtained azoxy products were isolated by recrystallization and the high purity of these products has been confirmed by NMR spectra (Figs. S5–S13). Then, the recyclability of Cot-MA-12-Nb was tested under optimal conditions. As shown in Fig. 6a, the catalyst can maintain remarkable catalytic performance even after five recycles in the oxidative coupling of aniline, demonstrating the robust structure for the single Nb site catalyst. Meanwhile, a hot filtration experiment was conducted to identify whether the oxidation reaction occurred in a heterogeneous approach according to Sheldon's work [61]. As shown in Fig. 6b, as the reaction was carried out for 5 min, the Cot-MA-12-Nb was grabbed out and the resulting solution was divided equally into two parts. One part kept stirred and another part was added to Cot-MA-12-Nb and continued on reaction. The results indicated that the reaction cannot happen anymore once catalyst was removed, and however the reaction of another part with catalyst proceeded smoothly. Moreover, ICP experiment showed Nb leaching in the solution was less than 1 ppm. The results indicated clearly that the reaction only occurred on the surface of the single Nb site catalyst and proceeded in a heterogeneous approach, which was consistent with the activity test in polar or weak polar solvents as reflected in Table S3. Besides, the spent Cot-MA-12-Nb was also characterized by diverse techniques. As shown in Fig. S14a and S14b, the morphology of cellulose fibers in the spent Cot-MA-12-Nb catalyst remained untouched, which was the same as the fresh Cot-MA-12-Nb. Meanwhile, XRD patterns corresponding to cellulose-I crystalline reserved and no additional peaks appeared, demonstrating that cellulose structure of cotton fiber did not be destroyed after five cycles (Fig. S14c). FT-IR spectra indicated that covalently grafted MA did not fall off, which was able to anchor Nb sites strongly, preventing Nb from leaching (Fig. S14d). Notably, the Nb sites in the spent Cot-MA-12-Nb still maintained atomic dispersion even after five cycles without the obvious aggregation of Nb species as revealed by HAADF-STEM image (Fig. S15). As inspired by the results above, the cotton fiber-anchored single Nb site catalyst was compared with the previously reported catalysts, and it can be seen from Table S4 that the TOF value on the present catalyst was much superior to that of the reported catalytic systems for oxidation of anilines to azoxybenzenes under mild reaction conditions. Finally, considering the robust structure and superior shape adaptivity of cotton fiber-based catalyst, the Cot-MA-12-Nb catalyst was mounted in a homemade glass device for continuous-flow oxidation of aniline with H2O2. As shown in Fig. S16, the Cot-MA-12-Nb catalyst was loaded in the isothermal section of the glass reaction tube with glass ball as support. Hot water ran through the interlayer of the glass tube to keep the reaction temperature at 60 °C. The reaction solution was injected into the reactor via peristaltic pump. As displayed in Fig. 7, the activity and selectivity of the product did not decrease after 40 h of continuous flow process Obviously, continuous-flow processes performed in continuous-flow reactor are more efficient than standard batchwise protocols and afforded much higher throughput per unit volume/gram catalyst and per unit time by use of the present single Nb site catalyst. Besides, the flowing reaction system can improve remarkably the safety and allowed the reaction easy to scale up. 3.3 Reaction mechanism It can be concluded from Fig. S4 that the H2O2 utilization efficiency on the Cot-MA-12-Nb was calculated as 100%, which excluded any unproductive H2O2 decomposition via a radical process. Moreover, it was demonstrated in the literature that Nb catalysts possessed low activity in H2O2 homolytic decomposition [62,63], which ensured their superior performance in heterolytic oxidations with H2O2. Consequently, it indicated that Cot-MA-12-Nb catalyzed the oxidation of arylamines via catalytic mechanism instead of radical approach. The observation was consistent with our previous work where homogeneous peroxoniobate-based salts oxidized arylamines through peroxo species (Nb-(η2-O2)). Actually, the cotton fiber-anchored single Nb site catalyst can be viewed as the heterogenization of homogeneous peroxoniobate catalyst. As shown in Fig. S17a (top), the Raman spectra of the fresh Cot-MA-12-Nb catalyst displayed a band near 895 cm−1, which was characteristic for v(Nb O), and no bands assigning to peroxo group (O-O) was observed due to the decomposition of labile peroxo group under drying conditions of catalyst preparation. Additionally, the band around 1097 cm−1 was ascribed to vibration of C-O in the skeleton of cotton fiber. However, when Cot-MA-12-Nb catalyst was treated with H2O2, the band at 895 cm−1 disappeared and the new band near 876 cm−1 emerged, which was attributable to the Nb-(η2-O2) species (Fig. S17a, bottom) [45]. Additionally, if Nb(OOH) were the reactive center, then adding NaOAc would lower the reaction activity. Actually, the addition of NaOAc had no effect on the reaction (Fig. S17b). Consequently, the forming preoxo Nb species (Nb-(η2-O2)) in the presence of H2O2 was catalytically active species for oxidizing arylamines into azoxybenzenes. Next, the reaction pathway was also investigated on the basis of the following control experiments. The equimolar N-phenylhydroxylamine and nitrosobenzene was mixed together in ethanol and the solution was stirred without H2O2 and catalyst at 60 °C. Interestingly, the azoxybenzene was formed almost quantitatively (Scheme S1a). However, the oxidation of azobenzene only gave a trace of azoxybenzene under the reaction conditions (Scheme S1b), further confirming that azoxybenzene was formed through condensation step rather than oxidation of azobenzene, in line with the previous report. Then, N-phenylhydroxylamine was used as substrate on account of that it was an intermediate in the course of oxidation of aniline. Interestingly, as shown in Fig. 8a, the consumption rate of N-phenylhydroxylamine was equal to 32.5 mol L−1 min−1 at initial state (Conversion < 20%) if equimolar nitrosobenzene was present even without H2O2. Nevertheless, reaction rate for oxidation of N-phenylhydroxylamine was calculated as 13.8 mol L−1 min−1 in the presence of catalysts and H2O2 without nitrosobenzene and the oxidation rate of aniline was only 6.8 mol L−1 min−1 with Cot-MA-12-Nb catalyst as revealed from Fig. 5a. These results indicated clearly the reaction rates were decreased in the following order: condensation rate of N-phenylhydroxylamine with nitrosobenzene > N-phenylhydroxylamine oxidation > oxidation of aniline. Hence, the rate-determining step for the oxidative coupling of aniline into azoxybenzene was the oxidation of aniline to N-phenylhydroxylamine. It can be observed that the present Cot-MA-12-Nb showed the outstanding activity, which was comparable with that of the homogeneous peroxoniobate-based catalysts. From the previous characterization (Figs. 2 and 3), it was indicated that α-hydroxy carboxylic acid grafted on the cotton fiber surface can lead to the highly atomically dispersed Nb sites by coordination interaction, thus forming mononuclear Nb(V) peroxo species to promote oxidation reaction. As showed in Fig. S3, the Nb species was existed mainly in the form of aggregation on Cot-Nb-IM due to the absence of α-hydroxy carboxylic acid as anchors. As shown from Fig. 8b, it suggested strongly that the aggregated Nb species (Cot-Nb-IM catalyst) showed much less activity than that of single Nb sites for oxidation of arylamines. Besides, Cot-Nb showed the very poor reaction rate even after reaction 12 h (Fig. 8b) owing to extremely low Nb content (Table S1). It should be noted that although Cot-Nb-IM showed a moderate activity, almost all Nb species was leached out after catalytic cycles, leading to serious deactivation of the catalyst (Fig. 8c). These results confirmed clearly that cotton fiber modified α-hydroxy carboxylic acid played a vital role in anchoring and generating catalytically active Nb sites. As indicated from Fig. 4, the uncoordinated α-hydroxy carboxylic acid group grafted on the cotton fiber still existed in large amounts. These free α-hydroxy carboxylic acid groups may exert a dramatic impact on the reaction as the acid-base interaction occurred between arylamines and the free carboxylic acid group [64]. As shown in Fig. S18, if Cot-MA-12-Nb was treated with sodium bicarbonate buffer solution prior to reaction, the resulting catalyst exhibited very poor activity compared with the parent catalyst. These results strongly suggested that the free carboxylic acid on the catalyst surface played a crucial role in promoting the oxidative coupling of arylamines. The acid-base interaction was further verified by solid-state 1H MAS NMR measurements. Initially, aniline solution was adsorbed on the surface of raw cotton fiber and the resulting cotton was measured by solid-state 1H MAS NMR (Fig. 8d). The peaks at 1.12 ppm and 3.56 ppm were attributed to residual ethanol. The peak around 4.86 ppm was assigned to -NH2 in aniline. Meanwhile, the peaks near 6.66 ppm and 7.01 ppm were ascribed to hydrogen atoms in benzene ring (Fig. 8d). When aniline was adsorbed on the surface of Cot-MA-12, the resonance signal of proton in -NH2 group shifted downfield dramatically to 5.23 ppm, and the signal of hydrogen atoms in benzene ring nearly stayed unchanged. Furthermore, the resonance signal of aniline adsorbed on the Cot-MA-12-Nb exhibited the same trend towards lower field. Thus from 1H MAS NMR characterization, the resonance signal of -NH2 in aniline shifting downfield was assigned to the acid-base interaction between amino group in aniline and free carboxylic acid on the surface of Cot-MA-12-Nb, which was favorable for the adsorption and activation of aniline in the oxidative coupling as revealed from Fig. S18. Additionally, it has been reported that more reactive peroxo species can be formed with the assistance of protons, favoring the intermolecular oxygen transfer [65,66]. In our case, the hydrogen bonding between the protons of free carboxylic acid group and peroxo moieties are not excluded. Based on aforementioned investigation on catalytic activity and characterization, a proposed reaction pathway was drawn and illustrated in Scheme 2. At first, Nb sites on the surface of catalyst formed Nb-(η2-O2) in the presence of H2O2. Then, the arylamines can be adsorbed on the catalyst via acid-base interaction with free carboxylic acid functional group, thus being activated and adjacent to the catalytic centers (Nb-(η2-O2)), which can facilitate to oxidize arylamines into N-phenylhydroxylamine (Rate-determining step). Subsequently, N-phenylhydroxylamine can be converted facilely into nitrosobenzene via hydrogen bonding interaction in accordance with the previously reports [44,67]. Finally, the produced N-phenylhydroxylamine and nitrosobenzene can be condensed to generate azoxybenzene smoothly. 4 Conclusions In summary, we have developed a facile methodology to construct single Nb site catalysts by use of α-hydroxy carboxylic acid-modified cotton fiber as green and sustainable supporting materials. The advanced characterization techniques confirmed that the mononuclear Nb-(η2-O2) coordination centers were the actual catalytic sites. Owning to the coordination between the α-hydroxy acid functional groups and the Nb sites, together with the free carboxylic acid functional group on the modified cotton fiber, the cotton fiber-anchored single Nb site catalyst exhibited outstanding catalytic performance for oxidative coupling of arylamines with TOF in the range of 1126–4806 h−1, which was the highest value among the current heterogeneous catalysts employed in oxidation of arylamines. More meaningfully, the atomically dispersed Nb based catalyst displayed a wide substrate scope. Owing to the robust structure and superior adaptivity, the cotton fiber-derived Nb catalyst can be employed in a continuous flow process for oxidation of aniline with steady operation of 40 h, which offers significant benefits compared to batch processes. The study on mechanism demonstrated that the reaction proceeded through catalysis instead of radical approach. Moreover, the covalently grafted α-hydroxy carboxylic acid can promote the adsorption and activation of the arylamines through the acid-base interaction in addition to the role of coordinating/stabilizing the single Nb sites. To our knowledge, this is the first work concerning α-hydroxy carboxylic acid functionalized support for the construction of atomically dispersed Nb site catalyst for the efficient oxidation of arylamines. We can envision that this work can provide a novel design strategy for single metal atom catalysts (Fe, Ni, Co, Ru, V, etc.) to further enhance their catalytic activities in the oxidation reaction. coredata.dc:description: This work demonstrated a facile methodology to construct single Nb site catalysts with merely 0.63 wt% Nb by employing α-hydroxy carboxylic acid-functionalized cotton fiber as green and sustainable supporting material. The as-synthesized catalysts have been characterized thoroughly and exhibited a superior catalytic activity for selective oxidation of aniline into azoxybenzene with nearly 100% utilization efficiency of H2O2 under mild and green conditions. Notably, it demonstrated the highest TOF (4806 h−1) among the currently reported heterogeneous catalysts. Moreover, the catalyst has steadily been operated under continuous-flow conditions, which afforded significant benefits compared to batch processes as reported in these transformations. The activity test and catalyst characterization indicated that the atomically dispersed Nb-peroxo coordination centers were actually catalytic sites. Especially, the α-hydroxy carboxylic acid groups on cotton fiber played an important role in coordinating/stabilizing single Nb site. Moreover, 1H MAS NMR spectra verified that there exists an acid-base interaction between arylamines and free α-hydroxy carboxylic acid groups covalently grafted on cotton fiber, which was favorable for adsorption and activation of the substrates. Mechanism studies indicated that the azoxy derivatives were produced through condensation step between N-phenylhydroxylamine and nitrosobenzene rather than direct oxidation of azobenzene. The work provides an economical and environmentally friendly approach to construct single–site catalysts for the oxidation catalysis.
coredata.dc:title: Cotton fiber-anchored Nb single-site catalyst for selective oxidation of anilines to azoxybenzenes
